title: How to Make Rose Vodka

steps.headline: Pour the vodka into a cocktail glass.
Pour in the lemonade and rose syrup.
Garnish with the strawberry.
steps.description: The strawberry can be whole or halved but it's best to remove the green leaves before adding it.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: This cocktail can be served with or without a straw, as preferred.

steps.headline: Arrange the petals into the mason jar or bottle.
Pour the vodka over the rose petals.
steps.description: Cover them well. If desired, add a few drops of food grade rose extract or essence. This is optional but can improve the strength of the rose flavor, depending on the roses used.

steps.headline: Place the lid or cap on the container.
Place in a cool and dry place to infuse for at least one week, preferably a minimum of 10 days.
Open and taste a little bit.
steps.description: If it's strong enough, it's ready. If not, allow to infuse a little longer.

steps.headline: When ready, strain through muslin/cheesecloth or a coffee filter.
steps.description: Pour the strained liquid into a long-term storage bottle.

steps.headline: Label and date.
steps.description: Enjoy the rose infused vodka neat or added to other alcoholic drinks. When serving, rose petals make a lovely garnish on the side of the glass. A dash of rose syrup can be added to the vodka to increase the rose flavor.

text: Rose vodka with lemonade Pour the vodka into a cocktail glass.  Pour in the lemonade and rose syrup. Stir through gently. Garnish with the strawberry. The strawberry can be whole or halved but it's best to remove the green leaves before adding it. Serve. This cocktail can be served with or without a straw, as preferred. Infused rose petal vodka Arrange the petals into the mason jar or bottle.  Pour the vodka over the rose petals. Cover them well. If desired, add a few drops of food grade rose extract or essence. This is optional but can improve the strength of the rose flavor, depending on the roses used. Place the lid or cap on the container.  Place in a cool and dry place to infuse for at least one week, preferably a minimum of 10 days. Shake every few days. Open and taste a little bit. If it's strong enough, it's ready. If not, allow to infuse a little longer. When ready, strain through muslin/cheesecloth or a coffee filter. Pour the strained liquid into a long-term storage bottle. Label and date. Enjoy the rose infused vodka neat or added to other alcoholic drinks. When serving, rose petals make a lovely garnish on the side of the glass. A dash of rose syrup can be added to the vodka to increase the rose flavor.
